data.title: Maronite Church
data.meta_description: feast and holy dates of the  Maronite church   Baptism of Jesus January 6 St Joseph – March 19 St Maron – February 9 St John Maron – March 2 Saint Rafka -  March 23 St Charbel – 3rd Sunday...
data.text:
Different to the western Catholic Church

They are both Catholic and must be subject to the Pope. The difference is in their backgrounds. Some things are done differently like the eastern rite say their Mass in Ukrainian or Greek, etc, whereas Western Rite used to always say theirs in Latin. Not only are they both subject to the Pope, but both must follow and profess all of the dogmas and doctrines of the Church. The Eastern Rite Catholics are part of the Roman Catholic Church, not the Orthodox Church. While the majority of Roman Catholics belong to the Latin Rite, the Eastern Rites provide a special length to our Catholic heritage and spirituality.

Sources: http://answers.yahoo.com/question/index?qid=20080814073249AARNKTu

http://catholiceducation.org/articles/religion/re0246.html

The rite that the church belongs too

The Maronite church belongs to syro-antiochene the one holy catholic and apostolic church. source: http://www.maronitejerusalem.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layout=blog&id=13&Itemid=17

The significance of icons in church

The word "icon" is originally Greek and means image, likeness, persona, figure, or portrait. The book Maronite icons: Modern Sacred Art, states that "an icon is a prayer in an artistic from example painting, picture, drawing or model. It illustrates the words of the Gospel, is true to apostolic teachings, and follows the traditions of the Church. An icon belongs to the liturgical worship of the Church.

sorece: http://maroniteinstitute.org/MARI/JMS/april99/The_Maronite_Icons.htm

Baptism

Baptism is the first sacrament of the Church to be received. It opens the door to the Christian belief and to the opportunity to receive other sacraments. Through the sacraments of Baptism a person (usually an infant) is washed clean of sins and becomes part of the priestly community, a child of God, brother of Jesus, temple of the Holy Spirit, and a sharer in the heavenly life. Without baptism, none of the other sacraments of the church could ever be received.

source: http://ololc.org/baptism.html

http://www.catholic.com/tracts/infant-baptism

Confirmation/chrismation

The celebration of the sacrament of Chrismation closures the call to life for, in and through Christ, and intensifies what Baptism when it is time to make your confirmation 13-15, it is your choice confirming that you yourself wish to be a Catholic.

source: http://resource.fraynework.com.au/object.cfm?o=205&pid=1475

Eucharist

The Eucharist is the centre of life and source of nourishment for all Christians it brings the Church together and unites us to one another in love of Christ. The usual age is between 6-7, this means that after they were baptised it is confirming that you are still in the Catholic faith.

source: http://www.adelaide.catholic.org.au/our-faith/sacraments/eucharist-holy-communion-

Interesting Facts

The maronite church is one of the largest Eastern-rite communities of the Roman Catholic church

The Maronite Church professes the same faith and beliefs of the One, Holy Catholic and Apostolic Church.

The Maronite Church is one of 22 churches within the one universal Catholic Church.

The father of the Maronite Church was a holy monk and hermit, Maron, who lived from 350-410 AD.

source: johnrobertg.global2.vic.edu.au/files/.../Maronite-Church-18r63ys.pptx
